text: The Oracle of King Lemuel
The words of Lemuel, \add the\add* king—an oracle
that his mother taught him:
What, my son? And what, my son in my womb?
And what, son of my vows?
Do not give your strength to the women,
and your ways to destroy kings.
\add It is\add* not for the kings, O Lemuel;
drinking wine \add is\add* not for the kings,
nor \add is\add* strong drink for rulers.
Or else he will drink and forget what has been decreed,
and he will pervert the rights\f + \fr 31:5 \ft Hebrew “right” \f* of all the ⸤afflicted⸥.\f + \fr 31:5 \ft Literally “sons of affliction” \f*
Give strong drink to him who is perishing,
and wine to those ⸤in bitter distress⸥.\f + \fr 31:6 \ft Literally “to bitterness of soul” \f*
He will drink and forget his poverty,
and his misery he will not remember \add any\add* more.
Open your mouth for the mute,
for the rights\f + \fr 31:8 \ft Hebrew “right” \f* of all the ⸤needy⸥.\f + \fr 31:8 \ft Literally “the sons of the needy” \f*
Open your mouth, judge righteousness,
and defend \add the\add* poor and needy.
An Excellent Woman\f + \fr 31:9 \ft \xt Prov 31:10–31 \ft is an acrostic poem \f*
A woman\f + \fr 31:10 \ft Or “wife” \f* of excellence,\f + \fr 31:10 \ft Or “strength,” or “valor,” or “ability,” or “efficiency” \f* who will find?
For her worth \add is\add* far more than precious jewels.
The heart of her husband\f + \fr 31:11 \ft Or “lord” \f* trusts in her,
and gain he will not lack.
She does him good, but not harm
all the days of her life.
She seeks wool and flax,
and she works with the diligence of ⸤her hands⸥.\f + \fr 31:13 \ft Literally “her palms” \f*
She is like the ships of a merchant;
from far off she brings her food;\f + \fr 31:14 \ft Or “bread” \f*
And she arises while \add it is\add* still night,
and gives food to her household,
and tasks to her servant girls.
She considers a field and buys it,
from the fruit of ⸤her hand⸥\f + \fr 31:16 \ft Literally “her palm” \f* she plants a vineyard.
She girds her waist in strength,
and makes her arms strong.
She perceives that her merchandise \add is\add* good;
her lamp does not go out in the night.
Her hands she puts onto the distaff,\f + \fr 31:19 \ft A stick or spindle onto which wool or flax is wound in preparation for spinning \f*
and her palms hold a spindle.
Her palm she opens to the poor,
and her hand she reaches \add out\add* to the needy.
She does not fear for her house \add when\add* it snows,
for ⸤her entire household⸥\f + \fr 31:21 \ft Literally “all her house, household” \f* is clothed \add in\add* crimson.
She makes for herself coverings;
her clothing \add is\add* fine linen and purple.
Her husband\f + \fr 31:23 \ft Or “lord” \f* is known at the gates,
in his seat among the elders of the land.
Linen garments she makes and sells,
and she supplies sashes for the merchants.
Strength and dignity are her clothing,
and she laughs ⸤at the future⸥.\f + \fr 31:25 \ft Literally “to the day/time coming after” \f*
She opens her mouth with wisdom,
and instruction of kindness \add is\add* upon her tongue.
She looks after the ways of her household,
and the bread of idleness she will not eat.
Her children rise and consider her happy,
her husband\f + \fr 31:28 \ft Or “lord” \f* \add also\add*, and he praises her;
“Many daughters have done excellence,\f + \fr 31:29 \ft Or “strength,” or “valor,” or “ability,” or “efficiency” \f*
but ⸤you surpass⸥\f + \fr 31:29 \ft Literally “you ascend over” \f* all of them.”

Charm\f + \fr 31:30 \ft Hebrew “The charm” \f* \add is\add* deceit and beauty\f + \fr 31:30 \ft Hebrew “the beauty” \f* \add is\add* vain;\f + \fr 31:30 \ft Or “vapor,” or “emptiness,” or “breath” \f*
\add but\add* a woman who fears Yahweh shall be praised.
Give to her from the fruit of her hand,
and may they praise her works in the city gates.
